projectPurpose: To provide an enhanced, more user-friendly command-line tool for analyzing and visualizing disk space usage, serving as a modern alternative to the traditional `du` utility.
mainFeatures: Tree-like visualization of disk usage in the terminal
Graphical representation of sizes using bars
Color-coded output for easy identification of large directories
More intuitive output format compared to `du`
Written in Rust for performance and memory safety

alternatives.name: du
mainFeatures: Summarize disk usage of files and directories
Calculate total disk usage
Support for various output formats (e.g., human-readable)
Option to exclude files or directories
Standard command-line utility

alternatives.name: ncdu
mainFeatures: Interactive text-mode user interface (ncurses)
Navigate directories and view sizes
Delete files/directories from within the interface
Sort items by size, name, etc.
Export file listing to JSON

alternatives.name: Baobab (Disk Usage Analyzer)
mainFeatures: Graphical tree map visualization
Graphical sunburst charts
Scan file systems or specific folders
Scan remote machines via SSH
Option to delete files/folders graphically

alternatives.name: WizTree
mainFeatures: Extremely fast scanning (reads NTFS MFT directly)
Graphical tree map visualization
Quickly identify largest files and folders
Export data to CSV
Find duplicate files

alternatives.name: TreeSize Free
mainFeatures: Scan and display folder sizes in a tree structure (Explorer-like)
Visualize space usage with bar chart and treemap
Show file count
Scan network drives (limited in free version)
Scan mobile devices

marketPositioning: dust is positioned as a modern, command-line disk usage analyzer that aims to be a more intuitive and visually appealing replacement for the standard `du` utility. By providing a tree-like structure with graphical bars and colors directly in the terminal, it offers a better user experience than the raw output of `du`. It differentiates itself from interactive tools like `ncdu` by focusing on a clear, static output designed for quick overview rather than interactive navigation. Its implementation in Rust emphasizes performance and modern software development practices.
